weapon.name: 2cm Flak 38
weapon.description: Despite its decreasing effectiveness against heavily armoured aircraft such as the Thunderbolt this gun remained in service till the end. In 1944 there were more than 20,000.

weapon.name: 15cm NW 41
weapon.description: NbW 41 150mm Nebelwerfer (Smoke Projector) rocket launcher was an artillery piece that fired rockets instead of the traditional artillery shells. With no recoil to absorb, the Nebelwerfer could be produced for one-third the cost and in one-half the time that it took for a comparable artillery piece. The NbW 41 was a six-barreled launcher that was mounted to a light two-wheeled trailer. Generally all six rockets could be fired virtually simultaneously, thus creating quite an impact at the receiving end. The rocket shells were initially used for laying smoke, but could also fire HE shells.

weapon.name: 21cm NW 42
weapon.description: NbW 42 210mm Nebelwerfer (Smoke Projector) rocket launcher was an artillery piece that fired rockets instead of the traditional artillery shells. With no recoil to absorb, the Nebelwerfer could be produced for one-third the cost and in half the time it took for a comparable artillery piece. The NbW 42 was a five-barreled launcher based on the NbW 41. It fired a shell that was three times heavier than, and carried four times the explosive charge of, the NbW 41. Mounted to a small two-wheeled trailer, it was easily manhandled by the weapon's crew.

weapon.name: 30cm NW 56
weapon.description: The NW 56 300mm rocket launcher consisted of a six-rocket launcher rack on the carriage of a PaK 38 50mm anti-tank gun. To give an idea of the immense firepower of such a weapon, in just ten seconds it could fire over 1670 lbs. (762kg) in projectile weight.

weapon.name: Panzerfaust
weapon.description: Way before its time, this was the original disposable weapon. Its punch was incredible but the range was desperately short and required nerves of steel.

weapon.name: PIAT
weapon.description: Unlike the Bazooka and the Panzerfaust, the PIAT operated on the spigot mortar principle. Despite its punch it was unpopular due to its weight and the difficulty of cocking the main spring.

weapon.name: 2.36in M9A1 ATRL 'Bazooka'
weapon.description: One of the most original weapons of the war, the Bazooka and its off-shoots revolutionised the battle-field from early 1943. It provided infantry with a handy anti-tank capability, and 476,628 were produced during the war, plus 15,603,000 rockets.

weapon.name: 2cm Flakvierling
weapon.description: One of the most feared low-level anti-aircraft weapons of the war, the Flakvierling comprised four 2cm Flak 38s mounted together. It first appeared in 1940 and served to the end.

weapon.name: 3.7cm Flak 43
weapon.description: By 1944, the 3,7cm Flak36 was getting replaced by its successor, the more modern Flak 43.

weapon.name: 8.8cm Flak 37
weapon.description: The Flak 18, 36 and 37 became the one of the most notorious weapons of the war. They were the "dreaded 88s" which were used to such effect as anti-tank guns by Rommel in the desert.

weapon.name: 3.7cm PaK 35/36 L/45
weapon.description: The basis for many anti-tank guns in service in 1939, the PaK 36 remained in service till the end despite its increasing ineffectiveness. By 1944 it was still in service with reserve and training units.

weapon.name: 5cm PaK 38 L/60
weapon.description: The PaK 38 was an extremely successful gun in 1941-42. But by 1944 it equipped mainly reserve and training units.

weapon.name: 7.5cm PaK 40 L/48
weapon.description: Really a scaled-up PaK 38, the 40 became the standard German anti-tank gun and was used on all fronts. Though heavy, it was a very potent weapon and was built in large numbers.

weapon.name: 10.5cm le FH 18/40
weapon.description: While it looked clumsy with its big wheels, this was a very good piece which threw a big shell, though not quite far enough. It remained the standard German field piece throughout the war. The late-war version was fit upon the a similar carriage as the PaK 40 to save on the production cost.

weapon.name: 10cm K 18
weapon.description: The K 18 was intended as the standard medium piece but was supplanted by the sFH 18. Still, many were built and proved very useful in the dark days of late 1944.

weapon.name: 15cm sFH 18
weapon.description: This was the standard German medium piece, equipping one battalion in each division. It was a good weapon, though a little out-ranged by its Allied counterparts.

weapon.name: 20mm AA Oerlikon
weapon.description: Originally a German design the Oelikon ended up being used by nearly all combatants. Despite its complexity it was highly effective, and was adapted to many variants.

weapon.name: 40mm M1 AA gun
weapon.description: The most widely used AA gun of the war, the Swedish Bofors equipped medium AA units in the Allied Armies.

weapon.name: 6 pdr AT gun
weapon.description: Developed as the replacement for the beleagured 2 pdr, the 6 pdr first appeared in numbers in the Battle of Gazala in May 1942. It was quickly overtaken by the appearance of the Tiger and was phased out of anti-tank regiments during 1943, although it continued to equip infantry anti-tank units.

weapon.name: 17 pdr AT gun
weapon.description: The 17 pdr was developed to overcome the inadequacies of the 6 pdr. It was the only British gun to compete with the German long barrelled 75mm guns. It was also mounted in the Sherman Firefly.

weapon.name: 25 pdr
weapon.description: Probably the most popular artillery piece of the war, the 25 pdr was incredibly versatile and effective. More than 12,000 were built during the war. This was the standard gun of field regiments.

weapon.name: 4.5in gun
weapon.description: The 4.5" was developed alongside the 5.5" in the late 1930s. It was unpopular due to the poor HE filling of the shell (only 1.76kg) and priority shifted to the 5.5". The 4.5" nevertheless remained in service throughout the war.

weapon.name: 5.5in gun
weapon.description: The 5.5 entered service in 1941 and became the best medium British piece of the war. It was very versatile and served both as a gun and howitzer in medium regiments.

weapon.name: 7.2in how
weapon.description: After Dunkirk the British Army had almost no heavy artillery. This weapon was actually an 8" barrel relined to 7.2". It was a poor weapon. The recoil was so strong it had to be relaid every shot, giving a very slow rate of fire.

weapon.name: 2 pdr tank gun
weapon.description: Theoretically the 2 pdr was capable of penetrating 42mm at 1000m. Early ammo lacked an AP cap and frequently broke up on hardened plate but this was fixed by issuing a new, capped type of AP ammo that was more effective and could take on 57.7mm at 500m.

weapon.name: 75mm M1A1 pack how
weapon.description: A variant of the 75mm howitzer. For the airborne role the gun was mounted on the lighter M8 carriage. A little light on for shell weight and range but an excellent weapon

weapon.name: 105mm M3 pack how
weapon.description: Oiginally a shortened version of the 105mm M2 field howitzer, the M3 entered service in 1943 and served in all theatres.The M3 105mm Howitzer was designed to be air-transportable. It used a shorter barrel than the regular M2A1 105mm howitzer and the carriage from the cavalry version of the 75mm pack howitzer, with a modified recoil mechanism. The gun served with the "cannon company" of six M3s in an infantry regiment and also served in glider field artillery battalions in 1944-45. It was used only by US forces. 2,580 were built during the war.

weapon.name: 155mm M1 how
weapon.description: First issued in 1942, by 1945 4035 had been built. The 155 was renowned for its accuracy. It was also the lightest of the principal medium pieces.

weapon.name: 8cm kGrW 42
weapon.description: The kurzer Granatwerfer 42 ( short mortar model 42 ) was designed for airborne units. Its extremely short range meant it was often used in the role previously fulfilled by the 5cm leichte Granatwerfer 36 ( light mortar model 36 ). It was also known as the Stummelwerfer or "stump mortar".

weapon.name: 8cm GrW 34
weapon.description: The schwerer Granatwerfer 34 ( heavy mortar model 34 ) was the standard German infantry mortar.

weapon.name: 12cm GrW 42
weapon.description: The 12cm Granatwerfer 42 ( mortar model 42 ) was a direct copy of a Russian 120mm mortar. It was extremely effective and even replaced infantry guns in the support companies of some infantry regiments and battalions.

weapon.name: 60mm M2 mortar
weapon.description: The 60mm mortars were not very powerful, but gave the company commander his own private 'artillery' that could bring immediate fire on the enemy from a mile away. Adopted in 1940, the weapon itself was a copy of a French design. About 75,000 were built.

weapon.name: 81mm M1 mortar
weapon.description: This was a copy of the French Brandt 81mm mortar. It could fire both light (7-lb.) and heavy (10.75-lb.) HE bombs and white phosphorus smoke shells. About 30,000 M1 81mm mortars were built during WWII.

weapon.name: 4.2in M2 mortar
weapon.description: Sometimes called "the Goon Gun", the 4.2-inch mortar was originally intended to fire only gas and smoke rounds, but by the time it was first used in combat in Sicily, an HE round had also been developed for it. Unlike most mortars, the 4.2-inch had a rifled barrel instead of a smooth bore; this increased its accuracy, but also made it more expensive. The 4.2-inch was used only in chemical mortar battalions, which were attached to divisions from the corps/army level. A total of 8,500 were made.

weapon.name: 9mm Sten
weapon.description: The British Army entered the Second World War without an adequate submachine gun of its own. During the battles on the Continent in 1940, the need for one was made apparent. At the time, only US Thompsons were available. In early 1941, a prototype was put forth by the Royal Small Arms Factory in England, inspired by captured German MP40s. It was named by using the initials of its its designers, Major RV Sheffield and Mister HJ Turpin, and adding them to the first two letters of Enfield, the location of a small arms factory and arsenal. The Sten Gun was first used at Dieppe by Canadian troops. It completely replaced the Thompson in Northwest Europe by the time of the Normandy landings in June 1944.

weapon.name: Vickers K Gun
weapon.description: Originally an Aircraft Machine Gun, the Vickers K Gun got its reputation through its wide-spread use by the SAS, which mounted the K Gun on its Jeeps.

weapon.name: 20mm cannon Polsten
weapon.description: The Polsten was a low cost Polish development of the 20 mm Oerlikon gun. The Polsten was designed to be simpler and much cheaper to build than the Oerlikon without reducing effectiveness.

weapon.name: 4.7cm KwK 173 ( f )
weapon.description: This was the German designation for the 47mm gun mounted in captured French tanks like the Char B1 and Somua S-35.

weapon.name: 3.7cm PaK 35/36 L/45 - Sf
weapon.description: The PaK 36 soon proved ineffective against Allied armour, but nonetheless some remained in service until the end of the war. Mounted on half-tracks it provided direct fire-support.

weapon.name: 3.7cm Flak 36
weapon.description: The Flak 36 was a versatile light flak gun and proved successful in a variety of roles, this one as a self-propelled weapon providing mobile flak and direct fire support for panzer units.

weapon.name: 2cm Flakvierling - Sf
weapon.description: The Flakvierling was a terrifying weapon with devastating firepower. It was extremely successful in the SP role and could give awesome direct fire support to ground units.

weapon.name: 2cm Flak 38 - Sf
weapon.description: Tthe Flak 38, the standard light AA gun of the German Army, was mounted on a variety of vehicles. As the end of the War drew nearer, its effectiveness against newer Allied aircraft gradually dropped away, but it still provided valuable mobile direct firepower for infantry units.

weapon.name: 1.5cm MG 151/15 Drilling
weapon.description: A triple mount of MG 151/15 AA machine guns. Mounted on the SdKfz 251/21 or on trucks, it was used mainly to provide low-level flak defence, but also proved devastating against infantry and soft-skinned vehicles.

weapon.name: 8,8cm RPzB 54 'PzSchreck'
weapon.description: Based on the American bazooka, the PzSchreck with a 200m range and a lethal 3.3kg warhead was a weapon any Allied tanker had to respect.

weapon.name: 17cm K 18
weapon.description: Excellent long range gun. Developed in 1941.

weapon.name: 7.5cm Flak L/60
weapon.description: The Flak L/60 was designed during the 1920s but turned down by the German War Office. Limited quantities were exported to Spain and Brazil. In 1939 undelivered guns were emplaced in coastal and fixed flak positions.

weapon.name: 8.8cm PaK 43 L/71
weapon.description: Also fitted into Tiger II, Jagdpanther and Nashorn, the superb Pak 43 was based on a highly efficient cruciform mount, which offered a full 360 degree traverse and a much lower profile than the anti-aircraft version of the 88 mm. It came to the front line in 1943. To shorten production time, a variant was developed which used a modified howitzer carriage. This version was known as the PaK43/41.

weapon.name: 7.5cm FK 40
weapon.description: The 7.5cm FK 40 was a slightly modified modified PaK 40 AT gun, to be used as an improvised artillery piece. It retained the AT capability of the original gun and was useful in HE bombardment. It equipped the light batteries of the Volksgrenadier-Division and of the Volks-Artillerie-Korps.

weapon.name: 7.5cm PaK 39 L/48 - PzJ 38(t)
weapon.description: Identical to the KwK 40 and StuK 40 except for a revised recoil system which allowed the muzzle brake to be discarded.

weapon.name: 7.5cm PaK 39 L/48 - PzJ IV
weapon.description: Identical to the KwK 40 and StuK 40 except for a revised recoil system which allowed the muzzle brake to be discarded. Mounted in the Jagdpanzer IV, the ammunition capacity of the weapon was increased to 79 rounds.

weapon.name: 12.8cm K 81/1
weapon.description: 51 gun barrels had already been produced for the scheduled PaK 44, when it was decided that the AT-gun would not enter mass production. Part of the barrels were then mounted onto the cradle of captured French 155mm GPFT guns instead to form the cumbersome K81/1. In spite of its great A/T-capacities - the gun was fitted into the Jagdtiger -, it was mainly used as a long-range artillery piece.

weapon.name: 57mm M1 AT gun
weapon.description: This was an American copy of the British 6 pdr AT gun, with the carriage slightly altered to suit American production requirements. Its performance was identical to the British equipment, especially in the later versions which included the British-style shoulder-operated free traverse instead of the initial American-designed wheel traverse.

weapon.name: 105mm M2A1 how
weapon.description: The M2A1 105mm Howitzer was the standard divisional light artillery piece. Towed by 2.5-ton trucks or in some cases by high-speed tractors, these guns were assigned four per battery, and could use thirteen different types of ammunition

weapon.name: 75mm M2 how - HMC
weapon.description: A variant of the 75mm howitzer, adapted for mounting in AFVs.

weapon.name: 3in M5 AT gun
weapon.description: In comparison to its contemporary counterparts, the US 3in M5 AT gun, was a heavy and clumsy design with mediocre performance. The US Army finally favored self-propelled weapons for its Tank Destroyer arm, and towed battalions were gradually being converted to self-propelled.

weapon.name: .50 cal Quad HMG - M51 trailer
weapon.description: This weapon consisted of four .50-caliber machineguns mounted on an electrically driven turret, all carried on a four-wheel trailer. The turret-gun combination was the same as found on the M16 AA halftrack. The combination of "quad 50s" and rapid turret traverse (the turret could turn 360 degrees in six seconds) proved a lethal combination against low-flying aircraft.

weapon.name: 8in M1 how
weapon.description: Based on a British 8 inch howitzer design, this long-range weapon had a reputation for great accuracy.

weapon.name: 75mm M1897A4 gun - GMC
weapon.description: Used on the M3 GMC, originally intended as a tank destroyer but given to the British with the advent of the M10 and later tank destroyers. The British used it to equip the Heavy Troops of some Armoured Car Regiments.

weapon.name: 15cm IG 33
weapon.description: This short barrel 150mm Howitzer delivered a 38kg shell and provided the much needed heavy firepower support for German Inf Regts.

weapon.name: 7.5cm IG 18
weapon.description: Principle support gun for German infantry regiments.The leIG 18 75mm infantry gun was a light, low-velocity artillery piece designed to provide advancing troops with artillery support. Six were normally found in the infantry-gun company of the infantry regiment. Overall the weapon was light and very easy to conceal due to its small size. The leIG 18 was introduced into the army in the late 1920s and served throughout the war.

weapon.name: 2cm Flakvierling - Pz
weapon.description: The Flakvierling was a terrifying weapon with devastating firepower. It was extremely successful in the SP role and could give awesome direct fire support to ground units.

weapon.name: 3.7cm Flak 43 - Sf
weapon.description: The Flak 43 was a versatile light flak gun and proved successful in a variety of roles, this one as a self-propelled weapon providing mobile flak and direct fire support for panzer units.

weapon.name: 12,8cm PjK 80 L/55
weapon.description: The 12,8cm tube of the scheduled PaK44 was mounted into the Jagdtiger.

weapon.name: 7.5cm PaK 40 L/48 - Sf
weapon.description: Really a scaled-up PaK 38, the 40 became the standard German anti-tank gun and was used on all fronts. Though heavy, it was a very potent weapon and was built in large numbers.

weapon.name: 8.8cm PaK 43/41
weapon.description: The PaK 43/41 had the same barrel as the PaK 43, but was mounted on a modified howitzer carriage. Demands from the front for more 88mm anti-tank guns necessitated this expediency, which negated most of the PaK 43's qualities (the new version was so big it was nicknamed the "barndoor") - though not its deadly ability to kill targets over 3000 meters away. These guns were usually found in independent towed heavy anti tank battalions, but also within Volks-Artillerie-Korps, were they performed a double role, as they were also being used as regular artillery weapon. In this guise, the PaK 43/41 was known as the FK43

weapon.name: 7.5cm IG 37
weapon.description: In 1944 a new light infantry gun entered production. It had slighty increased AT-capacities over the le.IG.18, but - more importantly - was also cheaper to produce: it was fitted to the carriage of the obsolete 37mm Pak36. The gun first entered service during The Summer of 1944.

weapon.name: 12,2cm sFH 396 (r)
weapon.description: This piece was a Soviet divisional level howitzer known as the M-30, During the early stages of the invasion of Russia, several M-30s fell into the hands of the German Army and were adopted as 12,2 cm s.F.H.396(r) heavy howitzer. Some were used in the Atlantic Wall fortifications.

weapon.name: 21cm M 18
weapon.description: Excellent long range gun. Developed in 1941.

weapon.name: 3.7cm Flakzwilling 43
weapon.description: The twin-barreled version of the Flak 43.

weapon.name: 4.5in M1 gun
weapon.description: The 4.5" M1 gun was a combination of a British barrel with an American carriage. It was replaced by the 155mm gun, but remained in service.

weapon.name: 10.5cm Flak 39
weapon.description: The 10.5cm Flak 39 can be considered as the 'larger brother' of the far more famous 8.8cm Flak, but its performance was not that much better. Being less mobile than the '88', it was mostly employed in the static role or mounted on rail cars.

weapon.name: 22cm M 538 (j)
weapon.description: Captured Yugoslav-made version of the Czech M28 Skoda heavy howitzer.

weapon.name: 15.5cm K425 (f)
weapon.description: The French 155 mm Long mle. 1918 (Schneider) was produced at the very end of WWI. After the fall of France, the Germans installed the gun in fixed defensive positions such as the Westwall.
